title: When writing music, my melody sounds like an already existing song. How do I create my own melody that can be in the style I like? - Quora

response.answer_text: Listen to loads of music in loads of different styles. Make time to listen to stuff you think you don’t like. Make time to listen to stuff you don’t know. Listen to everything and if you don’t like it, listen to it more. And write loads of music too. I mean, just keep writing - even if it sounds derivative or copycat. Keep doing it over and over, and keep listening and thinking too. And eventually (and rather paradoxically) your own personal style will emerge in your work. There are no shortcuts and there’s no substitute for just “showing up”. Day in day out, you need worthwhile and meaningful encounters with music. If you can’t write on any particular day (and I’m afraid that happens to us all), feed your imagination by listening and studying. The other way - to hide away from other people’s music and indeed from your own creativity - will not work. I guarantee it.

Alexis, if ur melody sounds like an already existing song, ur just assimilating it into ur brain. Obviously you don’t wanna end up like Harrison with My Sweet Lord. I mean i wasn’t there when he wrote it, but jeez, it really was very very close, I think he had to settle in court with whoever wrote He’s So Fine. Remember that a melody can be treated in a zillion different ways, so it doesn’t matter. Take Beethoven’s 9th. Ode to Joy. It wud be fun to write ur own chordal structure around it. Ur second question is more difficult to answer as i don’t know what ‘style’ ur into.

That’s the whole point. Don’t be afraid of the ““obviousness” of whatever melody pops into your head. The only way you can clear space for your “own” melodies is by giving the ones that crop up unexpectedly some life. Sing it under your breath, write it down, try to set some lyrics to it or find an ensemble that gives it its best life, and if nothing happens, no big deal, ideas are cheap. It’s what we do with them that matters.
Don't listen to any other artist when you write music to clear your head and do what comes naturally with the style of music you like.
